title: Nevada jobless claims triple from COVID-19 closures, largest weekly jump in decades
summary:
Nevada just saw its largest percentage jump in weekly unemployment claims in more than three decades as the impact of COVID-19 starts to make its presence felt across a wide range of industries.
Initial weekly claims for unemployment insurance nearly tripled to 6,356 during the second week of March, according to the Nevada Department of Employment, Training and Rehabilitation.
The sharp increase in the weekly numbers was seen during the week ending on March 14.
Continuing or existing unemployment insurance claims saw a slight decrease during the same week ending March 14 at 19,475.
Employer contribution and wage reports are used to help establish benefit claims made by employees who are filing for unemployment insurance.

title: RSAR Releases January 2020 Existing Home Sales Report
summary:
RENO, Nev. – The Reno/Sparks Association of REALTORS® (RSAR) today released its January 2020 report on existing home sales in Reno/Sparks and Fernley, including median sales price and number of home sales in the region.
During January 2020, the report showed Reno/Sparks had 377 sales of existing single-family homes; with a 16 percent increase from last year and a 27 percent decrease from one month ago.
The median sales price of an existing condominium/townhome in Reno/Sparks in January 2020 was $246,000; an increase of 33 percent from a year ago.
The existing condominium/townhome median sales price for January 2020 in Reno was $255,750; a 46 percent increase from last year.
The existing condominium/townhome median sales price for January 2020 in Sparks was $215,000; a 12 percent increase from last year.

title: Reno sees third-warmest January on record, Tahoe snowpack diminishing

title: Late season storms add up to a welcome 'half a miracle' for Reno-Tahoe snowpack
summary:
(Photo: Sam Gross and Benjamin Spillman)With communities across the Sierra Nevada and Great Basin desperate for good news, half a miracle is better than no miracle at all.
On March 1, following a drier-than-normal January and historically dry February, snowpack in the Lake Tahoe Basin was just 48 percent of normal.
The Carson River Basin was at 56 percent and Walker River Basin was at 42 percent.
The late season boost likely won't be enough to top off storage in Lake Tahoe and other reservoirs, but given how winter started it's better than expected.
That's because snow that falls in March and April is more likely to make its way into Lake Tahoe than January snow.

Unbeknownst to many, 108 of Washoe County’s 555 precinct have no registered voters.
Having few or no registered voters in precincts is not as unusual as it sounds in sparsely populated Nevada.
Unbeknownst to many, state election law caps the maximum number of active registered voters per precinct at 3,000, but there is no minimum.
In fact, 108 of Washoe County’s 555 precincts have no registered voters, county Registrar of Voters Deanna Spikula said Wednesday.

title: Columbus Day no more: Reno to celebrate Indigenous Peoples Day on Monday
summary:
On Monday, the city of Reno will recognize its first official Indigenous Peoples Day, replacing recognition of Columbus Day.
An intertribal group in 2017 lobbied the Nevada Legislature to replace Columbus Day with Indigenous Peoples Day.
CLOSE An earlier proposal to get rid of Columbus Day in favor of Indigenous People's Day was amended on Thursday to make two separate holidays.
The effort resulted not in the replacement of Columbus Day, but in the declaration of Aug. 9 as Indigenous Peoples Day, coinciding with a worldwide recognition of indigenous peoples by the United Nations.
Columbus Day lives on in Montana: Indigenous People's Day bill defeated by lawmakersReno is among several locations in the United States officially recognizing Indigenous Peoples Day for the first time this year.

title: 'Remarkably cold temperatures' forecast for Reno, outlying areas on Wednesday — 16 degrees in the city
summary:
Reno Gazette-JournalNear record-low temperatures are expected in Reno tomorrow morning, with a frigid low of about 16 degrees forecast for the city.
While Reno likely won't break its record low temperature of 13 degrees for Oct. 30 — which was set in 1971 — outlying areas north and east of the city might.
The potential record and near-record lows are expected on the heels of a very cold and dry front pushing through the region today.
That front has kicked up a brisk northerly wind that will keep temperatures in Reno on Tuesday down in the 40's.

This two-day event is an opportunity for those in the cheese and whey manufacturing industries to learn and discuss our role in today’s global economy.

title: OPINION: Defining Reno’s downtown

What Kazmierski describes already exists, in abundance.”The current “Entertainment District” was indeed once Reno’s downtown, back when the main business district spanned the blocks between the river and the railroad.
In the meantime, it’s time to acknowledge—and celebrate—the fact that Reno’s downtown is not what, or where, it used to be.
This is the “soul of the community.” If you’re going to define one area as Reno’s downtown, this is it.
That doesn’t mean abandoning the casino core, which is slowly diversifying with the addition of residential high-rises, non-gaming hotels, and other amenities.

summary:
Hundreds of participants and spectators turned out Monday to honor area veterans during the 2019 Veterans Day Parade in downtown Reno.
The parade began at the Virginia Street Bridge and continued north along Virginia Street to Fifth Street.
This year’s parade marked the 100th anniversary of Armistice Day, proclaimed by President Wilson Nov. 11, 1919.
He said:“To us in America, the reflections of Armistice Day will be filled with solemn pride in the heroism of those who died in the country’s service and with gratitude for the victory, both because of the thing from which it has freed us and because of the opportunity it has given America to show her sympathy with peace and justice in the councils of the nations…”

title: A timeline of the coronavirus crisis in Las Vegas
summary:

It’s a major blow to Las Vegas, which counts the opening weekend of the men’s tournament as one of its busiest of the year.
• March 14: Cirque du Soleil, creator of many of the most popular shows in Las Vegas, says it is temporarily suspending its productions in Las Vegas and around the world.
• March 16: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Las Vegas cancels Mass at least through the April 5 weekend, a week before Easter.

title: RSAR Releases 2019 Fourth Quarter/December Existing Home Sales Report
summary:
RSAR Releases 2019 Fourth Quarter/December Existing Home Sales ReportRENO, Nev. – The Reno/Sparks Association of REALTORS® (RSAR) today released its 2019 fourth quarter and December 2019 reports on existing home sales in Reno/Sparks and Fernley, including median sales price and number of home sales in the region.
Fourth Quarter 2019Reno/SparksIn the fourth quarter of 2019, the report showed Reno/Sparks had 1,516 sales of existing single-family homes; with a 15 percent increase from last year and a 16 percent decrease from the previous quarter.
The median sales price of an existing condominium/townhome in Reno/Sparks in the fourth quarter of 2019 was $226,000; an increase of 16 percent from a year ago.
The existing condominium/townhome median sales price for the fourth quarter of 2019 was $248,500; an increase of 24 percent from the past year.
The existing condominium/townhome median sales price for 2019’s fourth quarter in Sparks was $200,000; an increase of 7 percent from last year.
